author: By Marc Santora, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Unleashes a Missile Barrage, While Inching Ahead in Eastern Ukraine
description: Some of the missiles were launched from Belarus, whose leader is meeting Saturday with the Russian president.
content: From the skies above Belarus to the north and the waters of the Black Sea to the south, Russian forces unleashed a fusillade of cruise missiles across Ukraine on Saturday, Ukrainian officials said, in one of the most widespread and coordinated aerial assaults in weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Planned Parenthood of Utah has sued to block the state’s abortion ban.
description: The lawsuit argues that the state’s ban violates several provisions in the State Constitution, including the right to determine family composition and the right to equality between the sexes.
content: Planned Parenthood Association of Utah filed a lawsuit on Saturday seeking to block the state’s ban on abortion, which came into effect after the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: A Detroit Designer Works From Home
description: Tracy Reese, whose clients include Michelle Obama, returned to her hometown to reimagine her approach to making clothes, from top to bottom.
content: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: How to Discipline a Rogue Supreme Court
description: Make use of the constitutional system.
content: The Supreme Court does not exist above the constitutional system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Signs Gun Bill Into Law, Ending Years of Stalemate
description: The bill is the most significant gun measure to clear Congress in nearly three decades, though it falls short of more restrictive gun control proposals that Democrats favor.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Saturday signed into law a bipartisan gun bill intended to prevent dangerous people from accessing firearms and increase investments in the nation’s mental health system, ending nearly three decades of gridlock in Washington over how to address gun violence in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Jeffrey Escoffier, Health Official and Scholar of Gay Theory, Dies at 79
description: He wrote extensively on gay identity and history, but New Yorkers knew a different side of his work: his campaigns on H.I.V. and other health issues.
content: Jeffrey Escoffier, whose remarkably varied career included helping to shape public health campaigns in New York City and writing extensively on gay identity and how it has been influenced by gay pornography and other factors, died on May 20 in Brooklyn. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: A Year Away, a New Coach and the Same Goal: Winning Wimbledon
description: Ahead of her 21st Wimbledon appearance, Serena Williams discussed coming back from a tough injury, but steered away from political discussions.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — At first glance, it certainly looked like business as usual at Wimbledon on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Survive a Rental Bidding War
description: As the rental market convulses with a dearth of listings and intense demand, list prices can be deceptive. Here’s how to handle a bidding war.
content: Q: I recently attended an open house for a rental in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where the broker let applicants know in advance, via email and in person, that he would be accepting best and final offers on rent and commission. This was no luxury apartment; the building wasn’t new, nor did it have any amenities. I offered the listed price: $6,000 a month, with a 15 percent commission. He responded that he had already received offers for $6,800 and that I would have to offer more to be considered. How should renters respond to these tactics?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Eric Krupke, Sydney Harper, Carlos Prieto, Lisa Chow, Marc Georges, Ben Calhoun, Dan Powell, Corey Schreppel and Marion Lozano
title: Special Episode: Roe v. Wade Is Overturned
description: In a decision with sweeping implications, the Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion. What comes next?
content: The Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, a ruling that eliminates women’s constitutional right to abortion after almost 50 years. “Roe was egregiously wrong from the start,” Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. wrote on behalf of the majority, while President Biden has denounced the court’s action as the “realization of extreme ideology.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thessaly La Force
title: Christina Ricci’s Search for Authenticity
description: The actress, who grew up in the public eye, finally finds the role she’s been looking for.
content: LOS ANGELES — Christina Ricci knew there were great roles out there for her. She just had to wait until she was older. Not old — just older. Old enough to no longer be judged for how sexy she was (or wasn’t). Old enough that the men in the room didn’t think about her in that way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Warren and Tina Smith
title: Elizabeth Warren and Tina Smith: We’ve Seen What Will Happen Next to America’s Women
description: Roe is gone, but the fight has just begun.
content: The Supreme Court has spoken: Roe is gone. But the Supreme Court doesn’t get the final say on abortion. The American people will have the last word through their representatives in Congress and the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Wait for Little Kid Vaccines Is Over. Parental Exhaustion Isn’t.
description: The payoff feels somewhat anticlimactic.
content: Covid vaccines are available for children under 5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Americans Face New Abortion Landscape in Wake of Roe Decision
description: Around the country, a patchwork of laws was taking hold amid protest and celebration.
content: A new and rapidly shifting reality took hold across America on Saturday as abortion, a basic legal right for nearly a half century, was outlawed in some states, and the initial bursts of elation and shock from the overturning of Roe v. Wade gave way to action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Mayor of Embattled Southern Ukrainian City Urges All Residents to Leave
description: The request by the Mykolaiv official was somewhat surprising, given that the city’s combative, never-say-die spirit has become a symbol of Ukrainian resistance.
content: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — The mayor of this embattled southern port city, under attack from Russian forces since the start of the war, has called for “everyone who wants to survive” to leave, because “it’s not clear when all this will be over.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward and Aida Alami
title: More than 20 Migrants Die in Effort to Enter Spanish Enclave in Africa
description: The deaths occurred during an attempted mass crossing by 2,000 people over border fences into Melilla. Several human rights groups have called for an investigation.
content: Moroccan officials said on Saturday that at least 23 migrants had died and scores more had been injured after what the authorities described as a stampede during an attempted mass crossing into the Spanish enclave of Melilla, in North Africa. But human rights organizations accused the security forces of using indiscriminate force at the crossing, and have called for an investigation into the deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Lightning Shock Avalanche to Keep Dream of 3-Peat Alive
description: The Tampa Bay Lightning stymied the Colorado Avalanche in Game 5 of the Stanley Cup Finals to send the series back to Florida.
content: DENVER — After the Tampa Bay Lightning lost a heartbreaker in overtime on Wednesday to fall behind three games to one in the Stanley Cup Finals, the easy money was on the Colorado Avalanche to close out the series at home on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Gareth Bale Will Join Los Angeles F.C. in Major League Soccer
description: Bale, who helped Wales qualify for the World Cup, will prepare for the tournament in the United States.
content: Ever since Gareth Bale helped ensure that Wales would play in the World Cup for the first time since 1958, there has been only one question on the minds of his countrymen: For which club would he sign, and play, to prepare for the tournament?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The End of Roe Is Just the Beginning
description: An improbable anti-abortion triumph yields an uncertain political future.
content: By any reasonable political science theory, any normal supposition about how power works in our republic, this day should not have come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Leporati
title: At Pikes Peak Hill Climb, a Drive to Win and to Put the Race on the Map
description: The 12.4-mile sprint up to an altitude exceeding 14,000 feet is renowned internationally but more obscure in the United States, where hill climbs and rally racing are less popular.
content: Across the world, the Pikes Peak International Hill Climb is known as one of the most prestigious car races, a treacherous 12.4-mile sprint up one of the highest summits of the Rockies. But for many people in the United States, and even some in its host city, Colorado Springs, the race is hardly known at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Creeden
title: The Burger That Instagram Built
description: At Monty’s Good Burger, a chain in Los Angeles, there’s no meat but lots of selfies.
content: LOS ANGELES — Even if you’ve never eaten food from Monty’s Good Burger, there’s a good chance it’s crossed your path on the internet. It could have been the photo of Joaquin Phoenix celebrating his 2020 Oscar win by biting into a Monty’s a burger with Rooney Mara, or Travis Barker and Kourtney Kardashian sharing a Monty’s Oat Matcha Latte shake, “Lady and the Tramp” style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: Will the Specter of Monkeypox Affect Pride Weekend in New York?
description: Some say they have changed their plans in response to the city’s 39 positive cases, while others plan to carry on as safely as they can.
content: For L.G.B.T.Q. people in New York City, the last Friday in June is usually a joyful day. The streets come alive with the telltale signs of a celebratory weekend: music, dancing, kissing, the occasional trail of glitter confetti.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Court Widens Scope of Deportations
description: The Biden administration had instructed ICE agents to focus on immigrants who were considered a threat. But a judge’s order means millions more could now be targeted for deportation.
content: A Biden administration policy that prioritized the arrest of undocumented immigrants who are considered a threat to public safety and national security has been suspended as of Saturday, rendering millions of people vulnerable to deportation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Mr. Happy Face, a Chihuahua Mix With a Mohawk, Crowned World’s Ugliest Dog
description: He was the winner of a competition that promotes the adoption of dogs, even ones with perpetually protruding tongues and missing fur.
content: Out of a field that included a “hairless mutant” with no teeth and a crooked face, a creature that resembled “a hyena or mandrill baboon,” and a canine with a “gorilla-looking head,” a Chihuahua mix named Mr. Happy Face emerged on Friday as the foulest of them all, winner of the 2022 World’s Ugliest Dog contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of June 20, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Kirtzman
title: Giuliani’s Loyalty to Trump Was Born in His Darkest Moment
description: How America’s mayor got to this low point.
content: Shaye Moss, a Georgia election worker, described on national television on Tuesday the smear campaign that Rudy Giuliani waged against her and her mother. Mr. Giuliani, speaking to Georgia legislators weeks after the 2020 presidential vote, had accused the two women of engaging in “surreptitious, illegal behavior” while working the polls on election night and conjured a racist image of them “passing around USB ports as if they are vials of heroin or cocaine.” The fabricated allegations, based on a cynical misrepresentation of a video, were designed to persuade Georgia officials to overturn the election results in their state, and they triggered an avalanche of harassment and death threats against the women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The Day the Supreme Court Crashed the Title IX Party
description: Celebration of the 50th anniversary of Title IX was dampened as female athletes were saddened — and angered — by the Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade.
content: Billie Jean King and A’ja Wilson danced together at an awards dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Shareholder Advisory Firm Backs Spirit-Frontier Merger
description: After Frontier raised its offer for Spirit on Friday, the firm ISS reversed its recommendation that shareholders consider a rival bid from JetBlue.
content: The influential shareholder advisory service Institutional Shareholder Services is now advising Spirit Airlines’ investors to vote in favor of a proposed merger with Frontier Airlines over a rival offer from JetBlue Airways, after Frontier increased its offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: A New Task for Biden: Readying Allies for a Long Conflict in Ukraine
description: In March, talk of victory was in the air. Now, maintaining unity against President Vladimir V. Putin is looking harder, with President Biden heading to Germany and Spain to rally Europe.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Biden met his Western allies in Europe three months ago, the world was rallying behind Ukraine, and NATO suddenly had a new sense of purpose — its old purpose, containing Russia. There was talk of “crippling sanctions.” President Vladimir V. Putin was in retreat, and talk of victory was in the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Abortion Ruling Poses New Questions About How Far Supreme Court Will Go
description: The decision overruling Roe v. Wade exposed internal divisions among conservative justices about reconsidering other rights.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s decision on Friday to end the constitutional right to abortion concluded one battle for now but immediately posed another far-reaching question: whether the judicial ground under rights in other personal matters, including contraception and same-sex marriage, is now also shaky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Abortion access is shifting rapidly one day after the overturning of Roe.
description: The consequences of the Supreme Court’s decision overturning the right to abortion cascaded across the country on Saturday, as millions of Americans began to grapple with one of the swiftest, most expansive transformations to reproductive rights in 50 years.
content: The consequences of the Supreme Court’s decision overturning the right to abortion cascaded across the country on Saturday, as millions of Americans began to grapple with one of the swiftest, most expansive transformations to reproductive rights in 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper
title: Commando Network Coordinates Flow of Weapons in Ukraine, Officials Say
description: A secretive operation involving U.S. Special Operations forces hints at the scale of the effort to assist Ukraine’s still outgunned military.
content: WASHINGTON — As Russian troops press ahead with a grinding campaign to seize eastern Ukraine, the nation’s ability to resist the onslaught depends more than ever on help from the United States and its allies — including a stealthy network of commandos and spies rushing to provide weapons, intelligence and training, according to U.S. and European officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: The Leader of the QAnon Conspiracy Theory Returns
description: Three posts on Friday night signaled the resurfacing of a figure who used a variety of conspiracy theories to marshal support for Donald J. Trump.
content: After more than a year of silence, the mysterious figure behind the QAnon conspiracy theory has reappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Women who had their abortions canceled are now scrambling.
description: Trigger laws and centuries-old bans on abortion have forced clinics to turn away women who had already scheduled abortions before the Supreme Court decision.
content: After carefully weighing whether she was ready to have a child, a 21-year-old woman in West Virginia called the state’s lone abortion clinic on Thursday and scheduled an appointment for early July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Radical Reign of Clarence Thomas
description: An out-of-control court sends women back to the Dark Ages.
content: WASHINGTON — “What is happening here?” a distraught Nancy Pelosi said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finn-Olaf Jones
title: In Southeast Asia, Luxury Hotel Bargains Aren’t Hard to Find
description: The region is emerging from Covid isolation only to find a dearth of the Chinese visitors who once flocked there. Some hotels are responding with deals for travelers from the U.S. and elsewhere.
content: When newly married Marissa, 28, and Sean Cavenagh, 31, of Chicago decided to spend their honeymoon in Southeast Asia this summer, they planned to stay in Airbnbs and modest hotels while wending their way through Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam and Indonesia. But when they discovered the astounding bargains to be had at some of the most luxurious properties in these destinations, they radically upgraded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Belarus’s Leader, ‘Europe’s Last Dictator,’ Burnishes Links to Russia
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia  met with President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus on Saturday amid questions over how far Minsk will allow itself to be drawn into the war.
content: In the weeks before Russia invaded Ukraine, it held joint military drills with its neighbor and ally Belarus, massing tens of thousands of soldiers along the Ukrainian border even as the two countries’ leaders denied reports that the Kremlin was planning to go to war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: Michel David-Weill, Influential Lazard Banker, Dies at 89
description: A member of his firm’s family dynasty, he built Lazard into an elite player on Wall Street while keeping it a smaller operation than most of its competitors.
content: Michel David-Weill, an investment banker and scion of the Lazard banking dynasty who helped shape Lazard into a powerful global banking institution before he was bought out in 2005, died on June 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Dead Roaches That Ate Moon Dust Went Up for Auction. Then NASA Objected.
description: The sale was halted after the space agency claimed it owned everything associated with a 1969 experiment that explored whether lunar soil was dangerous to terrestrial life.
content: Unanswered questions fill the cosmos: Are there infinite universes? Why does anything exist? How much would one pay for moon dust digested by a cockroach?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sensing the World Anew Through Other Species
description: Ed Yong talks about “An Immense World,” and Terry Alford discusses “In the Houses of Their Dead.”
content: Ed Yong’s new book, “An Immense World,” urges readers to break outside their “sensory bubble” to consider the unique ways that dogs, dolphins, mice and other animals experience their surroundings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Supreme Court Puts Gun Rights Above the Human Life
description: The same week, President Biden signed into law a bipartisan bill on guns.
content: The Supreme Court this week embraced a vision of the Second Amendment that is profoundly at odds with precedent and the dangers that American communities face today, upending the longstanding practice of letting states decide for themselves how to regulate gun possession in public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni, Lauren Hirsch and Jenny Gross
title: Businesses Are Bracing for the Political and Social Fight Post-Roe
description: Reeling from competing demands from stakeholders — including activists, clients, consumers, shareholders and elected officials — businesses are increasingly caught in the middle of the country’s bruising culture wars.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Century-Old State Laws Could Determine Where Abortion Is Legal
description: In Wisconsin, Michigan and other states, abortion bans that were long considered dormant could determine if access to the procedure survives the overturning of Roe.
content: Abortion has become or will soon become illegal in more than a dozen states whose legislatures had passed so-called trigger laws, allowing for bans shortly after the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: How Elon Musk Helped Lift the Ceiling on C.E.O. Pay
description: The gap with workers widened even further as public companies granted top executives rich pay packages partly inspired by Tesla.
content: When Tesla awarded Elon Musk a multibillion-dollar pay package in 2018, the landmark deal helped to vastly increase the potential compensation of the chief executives at many of America’s biggest public companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Commonwealth’s Fissures Exposed at Week of Meetings
description: This year’s summit for the group of nations came as they grappled with the place of the monarchy, and as many were forging connections with powers like China and Russia.
content: KIGALI, Rwanda — As the leaders of the Commonwealth wrapped up a week of closed-door meetings, panel discussions and formal dinners on Saturday in Rwanda, this “family of nations” still stood at a crossroads, with questions remaining about its usefulness and whether it can reinvent itself for the 21st century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Decades Ago, Alito Laid Out Methodical Strategy to Eventually Overrule Roe
description: A slow-burning hostility to constitutional abortion rights runs through the career of the author of the Supreme Court opinion overturning them.
content: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 1985, a 35-year-old lawyer in the Justice Department, Samuel A. Alito Jr., cautioned the Reagan administration against mounting a frontal assault on Roe v. Wade, the landmark ruling that declared a constitutional right to abortion. The Supreme Court was not ready to overturn it, he said, so urging it to do so could backfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: The Voices of Men Affected by Abortion
description: In light of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, advocates from all sides of the issue have called for men to be part of the conversation. The Times heard from hundreds who wanted to share their stories.
content: When Quenton Albertie, 29, found out his college girlfriend was pregnant, he was surprised at first — and then elated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah and Kiana Hayeri
title: ‘We Have Nothing’: Afghan Quake Survivors Despair Over Recovery
description: With the economy in ruins and aid in short supply, survivors of the earthquake in this remote stretch of eastern Afghanistan wonder what their next move could be.
content: GEYAN, Afghanistan — As dawn broke over his village on Friday morning, Abdul Qadir dug through the rubble of his family home desperate to find a small sack of flour buried somewhere beneath the piles of wood and dust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Three Astros Pitchers Combine to No-Hit the Yankees
description: Cristian Javier dominated for seven innings, and two relievers finished the job, handing the Yankees their seventh no-hit loss in franchise history.
content: It took three pitchers, 150 pitches and 15 strikeouts, but the Houston Astros combined for a no-hitter against the Yankees on Saturday at Yankee Stadium, beating the best team in baseball, 3-0.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: The Joy in Finding Your Chosen Family
description: For L.G.B.T.Q. people, the bonds between friends can be liberating and transformative. Five of these close-knit communities tell their stories.
content: When Lenny Lasater moved to Georgia in her early 20s, it didn’t take long to find her family. She quickly met the Bickersons, a group of queer women scattered across the South who met through mutual friends and banded together. Each Bickerson had given herself a name that started with the letter B — Ms. Lasater eventually became known as “Big Star,” because she was active in the local theater scene and played in a band.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henrik Pryser Libell and Mike Ives
title: 2 Killed and at Least 19 Wounded in Shooting in Norway’s Capital
description: The shooting happened near a popular gay club in downtown Oslo, on the weekend when the city is set to host its Pride parade.
content: OSLO, Norway — Two people were killed and at least 19 injured early Saturday morning in downtown Oslo when a gunman opened fire outside two nightclubs and a diner, the police and Norway’s state broadcaster said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finbarr O'Reilly
title: Coal Dust and Methane Below, Russian Bombs Above
description: The war has added a new threat to the dangerous lives of miners in eastern Ukraine.
content: DOBROPILLIA, Ukraine — When Aleksander Maryinych enters a metal cage and descends into darkness with dozens of other miners for his six-hour shifts, the concussive thumps of an artillery war are replaced by the clatter of rail carts and the grind of machinery carving deep into the earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: An N.F.L. Rookie’s Back-up Plan: A Track World Championship
description: Devon Allen is one of the best hurdlers in the world. He’ll soon shift his focus to N.F.L. training camp.
content: Last month, Devon Allen ran the third-fastest time in the history of the 110-meter hurdles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: Requiem for the Supreme Court
description: The decision overturning Roe v. Wade is a stunning moment for America and for its high court.
content: They did it because they could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Supreme Court Throws Abortion to an Unlevel State Playing Field
description: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade shifted the abortion fight to state legislatures, where gerrymandering has given Republicans an advantage.
content: In his concurring opinion to the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh struck a note of optimism that democracy and the will of the people would prevail, even on the agonizing issue of a woman’s right to end a pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: The End of Roe
description: The Supreme Court’s abortion ruling will transform American life and politics.
content: The Supreme Court has overturned the constitutional right to an abortion in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: The Quest to Beat High Gas Prices
description: From changing their work hours to driving farther in search of cheaper deals, people have been making crafty calculations to grapple with expensive gasoline.
content: “I SOLD MY GIRLFRIENDS CAR CAUSE GAS PRICES ARE HIGH 😳” reads the caption on the video Justice Alexander posted online this spring. In the clip, Mr. Alexander, a content creator in Los Angeles, sits atop a horse and declares that he will now travel on horseback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maham Javaid
title: Occupied Mariupol is suffering deeply, its mayor says.
description: Mariupol, a Ukrainian port city that became emblematic of the savagery of Russia’s military campaign, is now suffering deeply under Russian rule, according to the city’s mayor.
content: Mariupol, a Ukrainian port city that became emblematic of the savagery of Russia’s military campaign, is now suffering deeply under Russian rule, according to the city’s mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Bonus Features
description: Matthew Stock and Finn Vigeland put on a cinematic spectacle, with a little something extra.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is the first collaboration between two makers of memorable Sunday puzzles, although they’ve been in touch since meeting at a crossword competition in 2018. Finn Vigeland is a transportation planner in Washington, D.C.; Matthew Stock works for a math education nonprofit in East St. Louis, Ill., and is moving to Florida next month to teach eighth-grade math.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Kavanaugh Gave Private Assurances. Collins Says He ‘Misled’ Her.
description: “I am a don’t-rock-the-boat kind of judge,” the justice told the senator in a discussion on Roe, according to notes from a meeting before his confirmation.
content: WASHINGTON — During a two-hour meeting in her Senate office with the Supreme Court nominee Brett M. Kavanaugh on Aug. 21, 2018, Senator Susan Collins of Maine pressed him hard on why she should trust him not to overturn Roe v. Wade if she backed his confirmation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura and Jeenah Moon
title: In New York, Anti-Abortion Centers Outnumber Abortion Clinics
description: Crisis pregnancy centers, which encourage women to give birth, prepare for a post-Roe world in a state that is considered a bastion of abortion rights.
content: Patricia Clinton was walking up East 149th Street in the South Bronx one afternoon last fall, ruminating over her decision to end an unexpected pregnancy. She was five weeks along, already a single parent to two children, and her finances were unstable. She wasn’t sure if the father of her unborn child would remain in the picture and didn’t think she could handle feeding a third mouth on her own.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Nonbinary Air Travelers Continue to Face a Male-or-Female World
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 25, 2022.
content: “It’s always extremely anxious for me as I have to take a false version of myself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henrik Pryser Libell and Mike Ives
title: Norway Mass Shooting Is Being Investigated as Terrorism, Police Say
description: The attack, which killed two people and seriously wounded 10 others near a gay club in Oslo, came hours before the city’s Pride parade, which has now been canceled.
content: OSLO — A 10-day Pride festival in Norway was cut short on Saturday after an early-morning shooting left two people dead and at least 10 others seriously wounded outside a popular gay club in downtown Oslo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: ‘Wild Swimming’ in Restricted Beijing Offers Refreshing Break From Rules
description: China’s congested and highly regulated capital is not known for either its natural refuges or its rule-bending. But swimming in the city’s lakes and waterways is a cherished, if contested, tradition.
content: BEIJING — Beneath a curving concrete overpass, behind a wall of green fencing, surrounded by the roar of traffic, a swimming hole beckons in the heart of Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: 34 Senate Democrats urge Biden to take action on abortion.
description: With little hope of legislative action following the Supreme Court’s ruling, lawmakers urged the president to take “bold action” to defend Americans’ reproductive rights.
content: WASHINGTON — A group of Senate Democrats sent a letter to President Biden on Saturday urging him to take “bold action” on abortion rights, a day after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, the landmark case that legalized abortion nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cause of an Uprising?
description: Adam Aaronson drops in with a slick Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Adam Aaronson is still in college, and he’s one of a coterie of young constructors who have come on strong in the last few years. This is his seventh Saturday puzzle since his New York Times Crossword debut at the beginning of 2020 — and all have been crowd-pleasers, with fresh and vibrant fill. Today’s grid has nine debuts, all in the Across entries; some are showstoppers, but there are also some great clues for ordinary objects that make this solve a delight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Nicholas Fandos
title: N.Y. Republican Quandary: How to Veer Right and Still Win in November
description: Most of the Republican candidates for governor are embracing conservative stances as the primary nears, but that may turn off moderate voters in November.
content: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — For most of his early political career, Lee M. Zeldin was a classic Long Island moderate Republican: As an Army officer elected to the State Senate, he worked with Democrats to champion causes like tax cuts, veterans’ benefits and even beer, protecting breweries in his district and elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Scott Cacciola
title: For Some N.B.A. Draftees, Making it to the Pros Runs in the Family
description: Three of the top five picks in this year’s N.B.A. draft have parents who played professionally, including in the W.N.B.A.
content: When the Houston Rockets selected Auburn’s Jabari Smith Jr. with the third pick of the N.B.A. draft on Thursday, it continued a tradition of basketball as a family inheritance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: John Legend and Chrissy Teigen Sell a Pair of Penthouses in NoLIta
description: The couple got nearly $16.8 million, making it one of the largest closings in New York City in June. The biggest, a Midtown penthouse, sold for around $56 million.
content: The musician John Legend and his wife, the model Chrissy Teigen, have bid farewell to their Manhattan home, and, it seems, to New York for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilma Wolitzer
title: Jess Walter’s End-of-the-World Fun
description: The author’s ninth work of fiction, “The Angel of Rome,” collects stories of lonely characters caught in their own versions of Sisyphean hell.
content: John Cheever, in his essay “Why I Write Short Stories,” said, “I like to think that they are read by men and women in the dentist’s office, waiting to be called to the chair.” Several of the stories in “The Angel of Rome” fit that temporal harmony, that confluence of waiting time and story length, while also offering readers/dental patients the pleasures of intensely affecting fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: For Conservative Christians, the End of Roe Was a Spiritual Victory
description: Many religious people who are opposed to abortion worked for decades to overturn Roe v. Wade. “It seems like an answer to prayer,” one said after the Supreme Court’s decision.
content: For nearly 50 years, conservative Christians marched, strategized and prayed. And then, on an ordinary Friday morning in June, the day they had dreamed of finally came.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Marc Santora
title: Russia hits Ukraine with over 40 missiles, including in areas that were recently spared.
description: UZHGOROD, Ukraine — As intense battles raged in eastern Ukraine and Russian forces pressed to cut off the supply lines for thousands of Ukrainian soldiers, Moscow unleashed more than 40 missiles on targets across the country on Saturday morning, including in areas in the north and west that have been largely spared in recent weeks.
content: UZHGOROD, Ukraine — As intense battles raged in eastern Ukraine and Russian forces pressed to cut off the supply lines for thousands of Ukrainian soldiers, Moscow unleashed more than 40 missiles on targets across the country on Saturday morning, including in areas in the north and west that have been largely spared in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Emily Cochrane
title: Leaving Wish Lists at the Door, Senators Found Consensus on Guns
description: The bipartisan gun safety legislation that cleared Congress on Friday was the product of weeks of fraught negotiations that started with both sides acknowledging what had to stay off the table.
content: WASHINGTON — Inside a pink-hued hideaway office in the basement of the Capitol last month, Senator Christopher S. Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, did something unusual for the start of a high-stakes legislative negotiation: Instead of a wish list, he came with a blacklist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt, Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: How the House Jan. 6 Panel Has Redefined the Congressional Hearing
description: No bloviating speeches or partisan rancor. Lots of video and a tight script. The story of Donald J. Trump’s efforts to hold on to power is being unspooled in a way totally new to Capitol Hill.
content: The typical congressional hearing features a pileup of long-winded statements — what some might consider bloviating. There are harsh partisan exchanges that can obscure the substance at hand. Visual presentations tend to involve an easel. The television audience is largely on C-SPAN.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Faber
title: For a Kyiv techno collective, ‘now everything is about politics.’
description: “This war has destroyed the statement that art could be outside politics,” the group’s booking and communications manager said.
content: Before the Russian invasion and the pandemic, Ukraine had become an increasingly popular destination for club tourists over the past decade. Among the highlights were the biannual Cxema raves — parties in factories, skate parks and even an abandoned Soviet restaurant that united thousands on the dance floor to a soundtrack of experimental electronic music.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Abortion Is Just the Beginning’: Six Experts on the Decision Overturning Roe
description: These passages are key to understanding the Dobbs decision.
content: These passages are key to understanding the Dobbs decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By KATE ZERNIKE
title: How Did Roe Fall? Before a Decisive Ruling, a Powerful Red Wave.
description: The downfall of the constitutional right to abortion began 12 years ago, after Republicans swept state house elections and passed hundreds of restrictions.
content: The downfall of the constitutional right to abortion began 12 years ago, after Republicans swept state house elections and passed hundreds of restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah M. Kessel and Emily Holzknecht
title: Turns Out These Anti-Roe Justices Don’t Believe in Precedent After All
description: Before they were confirmed, this is what these five justices had to say about Roe v. Wade.
content: Before they were confirmed, this is what these five justices had to say about Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Feminism’s Journey Over the Decades
description: Readers react to articles about a feminist backlash and the 50th anniversary of Ms. magazine.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 25, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 25, 2022.
content: An article on Tuesday about a risk of bias in death examinations misstated the amount of time Jocelyn McLean wrongly spent in jail after the death of her daughter. It was almost a year, not more than a year. The error was repeated in a picture caption.
source.name: The New York Times
